document.title: Regional Computer Security Officer (RCSO) Physical Security & Procedural Controls Checklist

boolean_question.question_text: Is an access control list posted for the computer room?
Has the computer room been designated as a limited access area (LAA) restricted to authorized personnel only?
Is there a visitor's log for the computer room for persons not on the access list?
Is the visitor's log maintained and current?
Is a DS approved spin-dial (S&G 8400, 8500 or XO7/X08) or deadbolt lock (Medeco) installed on the IPF/Computer Room main doors. (For nighttime access control.)?
Are the main doors to the IPF and the Computer Room equipped with DS approved pushbutton combination locks (Simplex, Unican -- for daytime access control.)?
Are the combinations for all push button locks changed every 6 months, when someone with the number changes positions or if the combination has been possibly compromised?
Is all the computer hardware located in the computer room marked to its highest level of classification?
Are all system peripherals labeled to their highest level of classification?
Is all removed and removable media marked to its highest level of classification?
Does the computer room have slab to slab perimeter walls?
Does the computer room have exterior windows?
Are any exterior windows protected with Shatter Resistant Window Film (SRWF) Mylar?
Are there any necessary window coverings?
Are any wall or ceiling penetrations (air ducts, etc.) larger than 90 sq. inches screened with 12 gauge expanded metal?
Is the computer room located way from areas subject to frequent use?
Is the computer room located above ground level?
Is the computer room not beneath water pipes or other areas prone to flooding?
Is the computer room located away from fire hazards?
Is the computer room located in the interior of the building?
Are electrical panels labeled to indicate what equipment they serve?
Are they located in an area with adequate protection from accidental or malicious power interruptions?
Is there an Emergency Power Off Control that is readily accessible?
Is the Emergency Power Off outside the main computer room door?
Does it have a clear plastic cover to protect from accidental triggering?
Does it disconnect ventilation system power as well as computer power?
Are data and power cables installed in a manner to avoid any potential disruptions to continuity of operations?
Are the fire alarms installed and fully functional?
Are the fire alarms annunciated at a location staffed 24 hours a day?
Are air conditioning and humidity controls and gauges located in the computer room (to ensure environment is within equipment specifications)?

boolean_question.notes: Architectual & Engineering Design Guidelines for U.S. Diplomatic Mission Bldgs, July 2003 Chapter 12, Section 12.5, Para 2.3
boolean_question.question_text: Is each computer room protected by a minimum of two 2.2 Kilo (5BC) CO2 and one 4A40BC multipurpose extinguishers?
Is there at least one spare extinguisher in stock.?
Are extinguishers mounted and locations "signed" or marked?
Is there a secure location to store backup media for AISs to ensure continuity of operations?
Is the media storage room protected from environmental conditions such as extreme heat, humidity and air pollution?
Are any wall or ceiling penetrations (air ducts, etc.) in the media storage room larger than 90 sq. inches screened with 12 gauge expanded metal?
Does the media storage room have slab-to-slab construction for the perimeter walls?
Is the media storage room kept locked at all times?
Does the primary entrance to the media storage room have a DS approved lock (Simplex or Unican)?
Does any secondary entrance to the media storage room have DS approved deadbolt locks?
Is SBU data that transits non-USG controlled space protected by use of encryption?
Are the encryption devices operational (bypass and plain-text modes disabled) and properly keyed?
Are there any USG-owned workstations in official or private residences?
Are all residential hubs/routers/switched located in suitable locked cabinets?
Are there any DoS-owned computers connected to any other USG systems?
Are there any DoS-owned computers connected to non-USG systems?
Is there any simultaneous connectivity between DoS connected systems and non-DoS connected systems?
Do workstations or servers have any unauthorized connections (dual NICs on different networks or modems)?
Is there any wireless (WAP) LAN connectivity to the OpenNet/OpenNet+ network?
Are workstations located in offices with DS approved locks (Simplex, Unican or deadbolt) for after hours access control?
Are all system components labeled correctly for Unclassified/SBU processing?
Are monitors positioned to avoid being observed by unauthorized persons or from the exterior of the building?
Are users maintaining the private nature of their passwords (not writing them on or near workstations)?
Are A/B or KVM switches being used between the SBU and Classified networks?
Are A/B or KVM switches used between the OpenNet and Internet LANs DS approved models (Raritan or Wang)?
Are the A/B or KVM switch boxes labeled to their highest level of classification?
Is there any PDA connectivity to the SBU OpenNet/OpenNet+ network?
Are workstations left logged on when unattended/after hours?
Are Data and Power cables installed in a manner that will avoid any potential disruptions to continuity of operations?

Are unencrypted lines transmitting unclassified information, when routed through unmonitored areas between facilities within a U.S. Government compound, encased within a protected distribution system (PDS)?
Are these AISs under the direct supervision and control of the regional medical officer or designee?
Are these computer systems containing medically privileged information connected to the SBU OpenNet/OpenNet+ network?
Do the doors to the health unit/rooms housing the computers with medically privileged information have DS approved locks?
